description: Recorded since c.1330, as Middle English rascaile (“people of the lowest class, rabble of an army”), derived from 12th century Old French rascaille (“outcast, rabble”) (modern French racaille), perhaps from rasque (“mud, filth, scab, dregs”), from Vulgar Latin *rasicō (“to scrape”). The singular form is first attested in 1461; the present extended sense of "low, dishonest person" is from early 1586.

adjectives.description: rascal (comparative more rascal, superlative most rascal)

entries.meaning: (archaic) Low; lowly, part of or belonging to the common rabble.
A dishonest person; a rogue, a scoundrel, a trickster.
Sometimes diminutive: a cheeky person or creature; a troublemaker.
examples: If you have deer in the area, you may have to put a fence around your garden to keep the rascals out.

entries.meaning: (Papua New Guinea) A member of a criminal gang.
